publicationStmt.authority: Transcribed from digital files available in RUcore

msIdentifier.repository: Special Collections and University Archives, Rutgers University Libraries
msIdentifier.collection: Rutgers College. War Service Bureau. Records, 1917-1919

revisionDesc.change: Finished editing Eden's letters. Added correspDesc and listPlace elements.

opener.add: From First Lieutenant August L. Grimme '19

div.p:
I have good eats, good quarters, and a good time flying
1st Lt. Grimme would be assigned to the United States Army Air Service, the precursor to the present-day Air Force, established in 1918.U.S. Air Service, vol. 5, no. 5. Went up this morning for a two-hour joy ride; went burning all over the country. It's wonderful, the distance one can cover in a flying machine. Was up about 7000 feet this morning. It was so clear that I could see the opposite side of the lake and got a glimpse of United States soil. It sure did look good, even so far away.

Have been posted to the Ninety-first Squadron this evening. Haven't any more time for joy rides. I was doing artillery observation this evening; it was my fifty-seventh time up; have done about twenty-nine hours of "solo-flying" - did three and a half to-day.

I have had three crashes, but they don't bother me in the least. Came down in a spiral nose dive a couple of weeks ago at a rate of about 150 miles an hour, but managed to nose the machine up again before it hit the ground - came within about fifteen yards of the earth. "Hungary Lizzie"
Grimme was training at a pilot training camp in Leaside, North Toronto, Canada. Hungry Lizzie, the ambulance of the Royal Flying Corps, would have been stationed at the edge of the airfield during flying hours. (the ambulance) came chasing across the field, but got fooled. We have a peach of an ambulance; it is a big white Packard with a regular hospital inside.

I will probably leave camp shortly, having complete my course here, and will go back to the University of Toronto for the school of aeronautics. Will be there three weeks, and then go to Camp Borden for aerial gunnery and photography. This latter course is a three weeks' course; and then I'm through and ready for my commission. We have tests and examinations as we go along. Passed my instructor's flying test the other day.

p.supplied: I tell you what you could send me-the Newark Evening News. I seldom see a states paper, and then it is from New York, Chicago, Detroit, Washington, San Francisco or some other town, but never Newark.

placeName.key: Rutgers Alumni House, New Brunswick, NJ

div.p: Kindly pardon delay in answering your communication but it was unavoidable.
August L. Grimme, '18, is stationed at Camp Hicks, Fort Worth, Texas in the 22nd U.S. Aero Squadron.
I have the pleasure of announcing the correction in my address from plain August L. Grimme to Lieut. August L. Grimme 22nd U.S. Aero Squadron, Camp Hicks, Fort Worth Tx.

Allow me to add my appreciation of the work you and your Bureau are doing. It was a fine idea and has proved a success, for once a Rutgers man, always a Rutgers man. Have read the January number of the Alumni Quarterly from cover to cover and am anxiously looking forward to the next number. No doubt my copy of this cherished magazine is not the only one to receive this treatment.

An American cadet tells me of
having come across Al Gaipa, of the Class of 1914, who is aviating as a cadet here in England. Would like to come across him and have a pow-wow about the Home of the Scarlet. I am now located at a flying school in the Midlands of England where I have undergone a course of instruction on the type of machine which I ex-pect to fly in France. Am going to another camp to receive a bit more training before going to the front.

Although I am shifting around so much, mail will reach me if addressed c/o Seligman Bros.,
18 August Friars, London, E.C. who are very kindly forwarding my mail wherever I may be sent.
Here's hoping the next Alumni Quarterly will soon be here and that the next weekly letter will contain continued good news of the Alma Mater.
Thank you very much for you letter of April 26th. I have been trying to get track of you for some time but have not succeeded and am surely glad to get track of you again. Best wishes and good luck.

The following telegram has been sent by our Commander in Chief, General Pershing: "All commanding officers ask that every officer and soldier of the American Expeditionary Forces
The AEF comprised the United States' troops who fought on the Western Front.Library of Congress would write a letter home on Mother's day. This is a little thing for one to do, but these letters will carry back our courage and our affection to the patriotic women whose love and prayers inspire us and cheer us to victory."
Pershing.

Today is Mother's day and a good opportunity to write you and say how much I think of home and you. But every day is
Mother's day for me. I will soon be in France. The thought of you will give me added courage and the knowledge that I cannot come home until the message of victory comes with me.
My Father asked me to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of May 17th, and to state that he would be very glad to receive a copy of your Quarterly.

He has asked me also to send you extracts from my brother's letters written from Abroad. In his last communication, he states, that upon its receipt he would be in France. Undoubtedly at this writing he is at the Front, and I am certain, one of the many Rutgers' boys who are upholding the best traditions of their Alma Mater.

closer.signed:
Frederick G. Grimme.
FGG HGP
Enc.

div.p: I make this tardy acknowledgement of your kind letter of June 6th containing letters from your brother. We appreciate your kindness in sending them and shall return them to you as soon as we possibly can have copies made. They have arrived too late for the July issue of the Quarterly but we are saving them and shall print them in the October number.

The present address of August L Grimme is #217 Squadron, 61st. Wing. R A F., France. The person to communicate with concerning him is, his Father, George Grimme, 75 Belmont Ave., Newark, N. J. or 1045 Sanford Ave Irvington N.J.

postscript.p: Sorry I could not answer your communication before today. Received a letter from my son today with the above new address.

div.ab: THIS SIDE OF CARD IS FOR ADDRESS

1045 Sanford ave Irvington NJ.
Dear Sir
div.p:
Your communication to my son August I have sent to his new address "
August L Grimme 1st Lieutenant Sig. R C. U.S
217th Squadron 61th Wing R.A.F.
France "
and requested him to answer your questions at once.

div.note:
RUTGERS COLLEGE
This appears to be a typewritten copy of an original letter that was not kept in Silvers's files.
NEW BRUNSWICK, NEW JERSEY
div.p: I am glad to say that I have been able to find out for you the date the London Gazette in which your name was mentioned for distinguish service. It appeared in the London Gazette dated January 1st, 1919 and was as follows:-

p.quote: "Officers of the Royal Air Force who have been mentioned in dispatches for distinguished service in War Areas:-- 1st Lieut. August L. Grimme (U.S.A. Air Service attd R.A.F. Flanders)."

div.p: A copy of this Gazette may be obtained from the printers Messrs. Wyman & Sons, Ltd., Fetter Lane, London, E.C. 4 England, at the price of four pence. (8 pence)

closer.signed:
C.W.E. Gibson
Captain
Assistant Military Attache

place.note: The newspaper clipping in Grimme's file appears to make a mistake with the name of the location. The aerodrome where Grimme was training would have been in Leaside according to A brief timeline of military aviation training in Canada.

place.placeName: Rutgers Alumni House, New Brunswick, NJ

place.note: According to Gorrell's History of the American Expeditionary Forces Air Service, 1917-1919, the men of the 22nd Aero Squadron landed in Liverpool, England on February 16, 1918 and proceeded to American rest camps at Romsey. "The pilots were sent to various training schools in England while the enlisted personnel, under the administrative officers went to Dunkerque... No records are available at present to follow the course of the pilots. (p. 4)" Given Grimme's mention of the Midlands, he could have been sent to any of several places to train, including: Royal Air Force Shawbury, Castle Bromwich Aerodrome, Coventry/Radford Aerodrome, Ansty, Whitley, Elmdon, RAF Libourne. Bromwich is a guess, based on the fact that another American unit trained here. See Military flying units in the south west Midlands
Belmont Avenue was changed to Irvine Turner Boulevard.
